dc:description:
BACH2 is a transcription factor that forms a heterodimer with MAF transcription factors to bind MAF recognition elements (MAREs) in the promoters of target genes. Bach2 deficiency significantly affected the expression of genes with super-enhancer architecture compared to those with TEs or no enhancer mark in T cells.
*BACH2* was first reported in relation to in 2017 (PMID: 28530713).
A de novo heterozygous c.71T>C transition in the BACH2 gene, resulting in a leu24-to-pro (L24P) substitution was detected in a female with lymphocyte maturation defects, causing immunoglobulin deficiency and intestinal inflammation. Recurrent sinopulmonary infections, bronchiectasis and intestinal inflammation were also evident in a father and his daughter with a heterozygous point mutation in BACH2, c.2362G>A.

Experimental evidence also supports a haploinsufficient model.
Bach2+/− mice had a significant reduction in FoxP3+ cells together with significant increases in CCR9+ and β7-integrin+ cells in CD4+ T cells. Immunized Bach2+/− mice exhibited minimal induction of both IgG1 class switched-B220hiCD138− B cells and B220loCD138+ plasma cells compared to WT mice (PMID: 28530713). 
The immunophenotype of patients with mutations in BACH2 consisted of compromised Treg cells, enhanced TH1 differentiation, impaired proliferation and defective B cell maturation and Ig class switching. Silencing BACH2 in healthy control B cells, significantly suppressed in vitro class switch recombination towards the IgG and IgA isotypes.

In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged.

evidence.dc:description: A missence variant that was reported in a father and his son with similar phenotypes.
Yes, E788K mutant protein was aggregated in the cytoplasm with relatively little in the nucleus

The variant is a de novo heterozygous c.71T-C transition in the BACH2 gene, resulting in a leu24-to-pro (L24P) substitution 

The mutation was found by whole-exome sequencing and confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

L24 resides within α-helix-1 (residues 18–34) of the BTB/POZ domain, a key part of the BACH2 homo-dimerization interface. 

The mutant proline residue likely perturbs α-helix-1 of the BTB/POZ domain and places a polar residue into the hydrophobic face of that helix, which would decrease dimer stability.
BACH2 protein expression by flow cytometry  was reduced in patient CD4+, CD8+ and B lymphocytes despite normal mRNA expression
A missense variant that was reported in father and his daughter with immunodeficiency.

The model system recapitulated the immune phenotype detected in the reported patients. However, more points would be allocated for recapitulating both clinical and immune phenotype.
Bach2 haploinsufficient mice have abnormal B cell differentiation and Treg cell numbersand impaired lymphocyte development.

evidence.dc:description: Proliferation (Cell Trace Violet (CTV) dilution) of primary patient CD4+ T cells in response to anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 revealed several immune defects including: compromised Treg cells, enhanced TH1 differentiation, impaired proliferation and defective B cell maturation and Ig class switching.
evidence.rdfs:label: Reduced T cell activation and proliferation

evidence.dc:description: Impaired regulatory T cell function are evident in BACH2 mutant patients compared with healthy controls and also with patients with classical IBD
evidence.rdfs:label: Bach2 is required for efficient formation of Treg cells

evidence.dc:description:
Two experiments revealed a crucial role of BACH2 in T cell proliferation and  B cell class switching. Silencing BACH2 in control CD4+ T cells led to a significant rise in PRDM1 mRNA and resulted in reduced proliferation of CD4+ T cells 


silencing BACH2 in healthy control B cells, significantly suppressed in vitro class switch recombination towards the IgG and IgA isotypes
Impaired B cell class switching and T cell proliferation are consistent with the phenotype described in the reported probands of hypogammaglobulinaemia and defective T cell function
evidence.rdfs:label: Silencing BACH2 in control  T cells and B cells

evidence.dc:description: A quantitative transcriptomics analysis (RNA-Seq) to classify the tissue-specific expression of genes across a representative set of all major human organs and tissues was combined with analysis with antibody-based profiling of the same tissues revealed preferential expression of BACH2 in lymph nodes
